55. I ran UFED's Physical Analyzer on the Cellebrite
Extraction. Physical Analyzer is a separate program on
the desktop that allows a user to view extracted data,
search for key words, and run other analytical functions. I
used it to examine the contents of the Extraction and to
reconstruct and view Oder's text message communi-cations.
UFED identified and reconstructed Oder's deleted text
messages.
56.   I also used a second program, called XRY
Complete, to forensically image Oder's cell phone. I used
XRY's companion program, XAMN Spotlight, which is XRY' s
equivalent to UFED Physical Analyzer, to view the XRY data
extractions and to conduct key word searches.
57.   After I extracted the data from Oiler's cell phone,
I examined it with UFED and XRY. I compared the results
with the extraction from Oder's iCloud account. The im-ages
were similar, but not identical.
58.   Many files, including his text messages, were
encrypted with Signal. Physical analyzer identified
Oder's use of Signal. Physical Analyzer was able to
partially decode some of the Signal files. Physical
Analyzer allowed me to view Oder's text messages, but not
the messages of the people Oder communicated with. The
other parties' messages were blank.
59. I did not attempt to decrypt the Signal messages,
which would have required special tools and was beyond the
scope of my retention.
60.   I also reviewed Oder's recovered text message files
in an effort to confirm that they correlated with his
banking records, or specifically, his use of his debit card
ending in 9195. I was able to confirm that the messages
correlated with his use of that card.
61.   In addition, I reviewed text messages with the
search terms "Ed," "Eddie," and "Card Connect," which
resulted in hits. However, I did not see any text message
that appeared responsive to Shift4! s subpoena or the Court's
Order compelling the production of documents responsive to
the subpoena.
